title: Will Turkey impose capital controls before 1 December 2016 ?
preds: Considering the turkish economy structure, i think it would not be possible over the period of 3 years.

I almost would give this probability +x% for the question being posted in the first place. Whats up?
I don't believe Turkey's president will impose capital controls. Erdogan has done some extreme things in the business and finance markets, including purging the Capital Markets Board.

The intense debate in Turkey about transition from the countryâ€™s parliamentary democracy to a presidential system is having a negative impact on the national economy, Turkish economist and journalist Erdal Saglam told Sputnik.
"The industrial production in Turkey is maintained from the outside with money inflows. But we see that the economy is slowing down due to a drop in capital inflows to Turkey. The reasons are global economic trends as well as Turkish domestic political and economic problems," the economist pointed out.
Earlier this year, the Turkish government predicted a five percent growth, but then the outlook was adjusted to three percent. This has had a direct impact on people and their consumption.
"This trend is more visible in certain sectors, and in some it is less visible. But overall it is having a negative impact on the economy. Many major companies have been shutting down. 
Read more: https://sputniknews.com/business/201610291046874500-erdogan-turkish-economy/

Even with time short, the reactions after the coup attempt have helped him further consolidate his authority which is moving further away from the democratic environment he was part of.  He has also weakened EU and US relations but Turkey is still key to them.  Turkey remains dependent on foreign capital so the potential mis-step and triggers are in place.

I see that a Deputy PM has ruled out capital controls and the Turkish central bank says macro fundamentals are sound. Famous last words.

Dropping a bit, given Turkey's attempt to normalize relations with several countries. They're still facing economic headwinds though, and the imposition of capital controls isn't all that unusual internationally.

I am staying with this prediction but if news in June doesn't shift things I will recalibrate substantially.  If either a Fed rate raise or Brexit causes an emerging market sell off then cap controls could still be on the table. Otherwise the Turks will probably get through the year without it.
Fed on hold means less pressure on EM.
Time ticking by, reducing from my previous 8% to 6%. Recent dollar weakening helpful to Turkey as well given current account deficit, just do not see this happening this year.
Going down again. Syria is calming down, EU migrant issues are being digested, I think Turkey can keep a lid on things until the end of the year.

Looking at the past, the countries that have surprised by imposing capital controls, were on a different footing as compared to Turkey. It can at best be considered a threatening stance by Turkey and market players to ripple a bit in the bond markets. Fund managers too love rumors which they use to hedge. Before December 1 2016 there is zero chance of Turkey actually going ahead and imposing capital controls.
See signs that Turkey is stabilising on international markets.
As 2016 progresses, these controls will prove necessary to maintain financial stability.

lol, with fat nato contracts and crazy russia there is plenty of war for expansive deals as part of gdp, spin off tech will feed civil tech growth, turkey is actually growing regional power, there is zero chance of turkey f ucking up

Turkey has never imposed capital controls before.

Although Turkey has a tough geographic address right now, the economic stats feel fine.  They continue to have a negative outlook from the rating agencies but remain BB+, Baa3 & BBB-.  Capital flows have moderated after some bumps last year, business confidence remains fine, consumer confidence has stabilized, rates and fx are in familiar ranges, growth and unemployment could improve but are not cautionary.  Hence, an okay economic situation with a lot of turmoil from the geographic location which is supported by the key they provide to the EU and US.  No change on the forecast as there is still plenty of time.
Money coming from the EU, FED holds on rates.

EU deal with Turkey on migrants plus no visa to EU should make it less likely Turkey will impose capital controls. Turkish economy seems to be stabilising. On other side Erdogan continuing internal power grab is worrying.
Russia has crippled Turkey's ability to trade with Central Asian nations by denying its 18-wheelers passage through Russian territory.
Going down a bit. Noting Fitch rating as "stable". Even if the actual rating isn't great, the stability part is probably more important to the question of capital controls.

The economy will continue to suffer.  Many additional refugees as opposition to Syrian government fails and the outlet to Europe closes.  Russia payback to Turkey by aiding Kurds will increase internal conflict. On top of that the general slow down in world economic activity and trade will pressure Turkeys currency.  Capital controls are coming.

Lowering based on @Agent0090 link and comment:

Has Turkey crossed the Rubicon in its escalating attacks on the Azaz, Syria area? I doubt that this will work out as well as it did for Julius Caesar. What if Russia retaliates with attacks inside Turkey's borders? This also affects the Akkuyu and Turkey capital controls questions, IMHO raising probabilities, and decreasing probabilities of Article 4, 5 regarding Islamic State, which seems content to let Turkey and the Kurd + Russia + Syria alliance du jour duke it out for the foreseeable future.

Dateline 2-19-16 Turkish military hit PYD/YPG targets in Syria on Thursday night with artillery rockets positioned in southern Hatay province.
According to reports, the rockets targeting PYD/YPG positions in Syria's Afrin were launched late Thursday and continued to hit the targets on Friday morning.
Turkey pounded PYD/YPG targets near Syria's Azaz on Thursday with T-155 Fırtına howitzers, in retaliation for the terrorist organization's cross-border fire into southern border town Kilis.
Previously, the military shelled YPG targets near the town of Azaz in northern Syria on Feb. 13, under the rules of engagement and in response to two separate attacks carried out by YPG and Assad forces on a Turkish military base and a police station. http://www.dailysabah.com/politics/2016/02/19/turkey-hits-ypgpyd-targets-with-artillery-rockets

imposing capital controls is rare enough. Iran may open up as a trade partner in the upcoming months.  Biggest issue that I see is potential downfall of the EU, which is a non-zero possibility. And anything can happen before years' end. no way to make a truly accurate prediction right now, and at least one analytic firm put the odds at 50-50 by years end.

While the global economy is not in a good way, and Turkey is more susceptible than most economies to terrorism and sensitive to crises in China, I agree with others here - it would be a big step, and arguably a counter-productive one. I think Turkey will ride it out. There will likely be other measures the government can take short of capital controls to help buoy the economy in the medium term (interest rates, taxes, etc).

Capital controls have been imposed very infrequently as compared to how often financial problems appear.  In particular, the last decade or so there have been capital controls to Greece, Cyprus, Argentina and Iceland.  All of these countries also have a very small economy (Argentina might be a small outlier). Turkey is clearly a larger economy as compared to Greece, Cyprus and Iceland (and potentially Argentina) and hence, capital controls might really paralyze the whole financial and economic sector.  Hence, I give a very small probability of capital controls being imposed in Turkey.

I'll stick it out here for a while. If China were to announce a tightening of capital controls, or had a big bang devaluation  or both, I think there would be a stampede for the EM exits and Turkey would have to impose cap controls. Otherwise things seem to be hanging fire generally, so I may want to revise this probability downwards for the time period of this question
Lowering prob. Looks like G20 may be stepping in to reduce volatility:
the fighting with ISIL has stabilized the turkish lira a little, enough that gov. control is not necessary

USD bear mkt has begun... most important trading partner is europe though, and the exchange rate to the euro hasn't been that crazy: http://finance.yahoo.com/echarts?s=EURTRY=X&t=5d&l=on&z=m&q=l&c=#{"range":"5y","allowChartStacking":true}

Erdogan is a moderately strange guy (which is not the same as a strangely moderate one), but he might be concerned that folks would interpret capital controls as a sign of weakness--which is not necessarily the case--and so hesitate to go that way.  He is not erratic in the North Korea sense, but he is a mite unpredictable, sort of like Tito used to be. One lacks confidence in one's guesses on this one. (Full disclosure:  The guesses I do have confidence in are not infrequently wrong, too.)
Going up 5% to come up to consensus and also reflecting recent difficulties regarding refugees and Russia.

This is quite possible. The exchange rate risk they run is significant anyway, challenging them from a traditional markets perspective as TRY/USD moves against them. This is then compounded by trading issues between them and key neighbors as well as key partners such as Russia. It is not inconceivable, given the govts leaning, that certain 'protections' are imposed and possibly with short notice.  what makes me less certain is the timing before year end, from where we are now it would take a still material shift in circumstances to prompt this, the country isn't teetering anywhere near the brink of such actions just yet despite everything.

Continue slowdown among the EMs will place further pressure on the lira. However, US rates look unlikely to rise again in the short term. This provides a bit of a counter. However, further ISIS attacks will add to foreign investor concerns.

Knowing Erdogan; it is likely that capital controls will be in place. There is a bit of uncertainty in that prediction; owing to the fact that other countries have done so (China) and have faced even more outflow.

Capital controls have become fashionable again (IMF likes them and the Economist of all outfits thinks they're maybe a good idea for China). So that right there ought to raise the baseline case for Turkey. Why? Because nobody without steel nerves can be confident in any EM market if people aren't confident about even the mother of all EMs, China. But as always there is the other hand-US less likely to proceed with steady rate hikes, ECB likely to do QE etc. But meanwhile uncertainty and therefore volatility build. One more bad story about Turkey might just do the trick to lead to big time capital outflows.  But German aid (only to block further mass exodus of refugees) might still stabilize things.
The more I've thought about this question, it may be that I was low with my initial prediction, so am upping it.

Currency has already fallen a lot, would require Syrian problems to cross into turkey and shake my nice stirs. EU likely to give aid to turkey to prevent syrian problems coming in. Russians don't want to battle Turks. Lower for longer oil helps their balance of payments. Currency already moved more than 2008 but they offer attractive yield and ECB fed, BoJ going to have to do more stimulus so no funding crisis
Some analysts argue Turkey is a particular risk, as its heavy foreign debt burden is almost entirely denominated in foreign currencies, mainly US dollars and euros.
Political instability and knee jerk reaction should be the catalysts.

The central bank of turkey still have strong reserve. (http://www.tradingeconomics.com/turkey/foreign-exchange-reserves) 
They are likely to increase the rate before imposing capital controls.
Furthermore the central bank hasn't done any intervention yet.
I am not going below 10% because the currency is very weak.
Backing off a little since there may be payments from US to keep foreign reserves up as Turkey fights the proxy war for Nato.

Backing off by 10% since the scorers apparently have decided that Turkey's recent imposition of what looks like capital controls to me doesn't look like capital controls to them. This is turning into one of those "predict the scorers" questions. As Turkey further tightens the screws, at some point the scorers will say, "Aha!"

Thanks to those who posted the Al Monitor article. I don't believe that the Dec. 30 changes described amount to a capital controls, but they come very close to it, and are probably part of plan that could see controls implemented quickly if needed. (I also think it gives the government the opportunity to jail people who are politically disfavored.)

Turkey is too important to the West for any non-west, non-aggressor state to push Turkey to impose capital controls on anyone 
OTHER THAN RUSSIA.
Erdogan is becoming to extreme for rich people to feel safe in the near future.

Declaration : I have visited Turkey once 10 years ago, different world then it seems...
(then I had no security concerns walking the streets across the country and in Northern Cyprus)

Reaffirming my coinflip estimate, I submitted the following for resolution as of 30 December. I think it is a form of capital control but don't know if the judges will agree.

In addition to what austerity excerpted:
I'm not sure this qualifies as "capital controls", but looks a step in that direction

While recent bombings (hits tourism , source  of euros) and the general global situation  is negative for the Turkish economy, Germany is likely now to  see Turkey as a vital interest (only Turkey can really slow immigration from Middle East). Merkel is through unless immigration slows.  So German taxpayers will be on the hook for Turkey.

Capital controls would most likely be triggered by a currency crisis or banking crisis, as occurred in Iceland (2005) Cyprus (2013) and Greece (2015).  Turkey is especially vulnerable to this type of crisis because its banks rely more on international borrowing than most.   Moody's says, "Weighing increasingly negatively on the risk profile of the system is its funding structure and vulnerability to shifts in international investor sentiment"
leading party's political, social and economical relations will not allow to do that..
Turkey did not impose capital controls in 2008/09, unlikely for them to do anything this year
Large short term debt w/high global/EM instability
EMs are gonna get hit hard by dollar strength this year.
It will have little choice but  to impose capital controls if there is a flight of capital. So the question is really how likely is it that there will be a flight of capital, hence my prediction

Came across this quote today in my research on this question : "Authoritative research recently published by the National Bureau of Economic Research, the
International Monetary Fund, and elsewhere has found that limits on the inflow of short-termcapital into developing nations can stem the development of dangerous asset bubbles and currency appreciations and generally grant nations more autonomy in monetary policy-making" - (from article found on this site: http://www.ase.tufts.edu/gdae/policy_research/CapCtrlsLetter.pdf). It seems capital controls are much more popular amongst economists than I previously thought.

Dateline 1-7-16 The lira has been particularly vulnerable to changes in global sentiment since last month when the central bank left interest rates unchanged contrary to expectations of a hike, renewing fears about the rate setter's independence.

I am borrowing this rationale from another participant and adding my two cents: 2 years of the past 25 have had financial crises and 75% odds on capital controls if a financial crisis occurs (2/25*.75=.06). I am going to set my probability of a financial crisis higher for Turkey than 8% (2/25) given its rapid debt growth over the past 5 years.  I am setting my probability of capital controls high in the event of a crisis due to the country's reliance on USD financing.
Odds on a financial crisis in Turkey: 25% 
Odds of capital controls in the event of financial crisis: 75% 
Odds of capital controls before 12/1/16: (.25*.75)=18.75%
I'll hold steady on this one for now. FT cited a report that Turkey was likely in for a ratings downgrade.
Unlikely because the Turkish leader does not like the idea of appearing to be forced into things

Turkish foreing exchange reserves are close to historic high. Trade deficit went down some 50% in 2015, and is now close to its lowest in last 5 years. Turkish New Lira devaluated 20% from 2.4 to 2.9 for 1 us$ in 2015, and inflation rate was only about 8%. Things must go really bad in 2016 if we are to expect a situation so difficult to call for capital controls.

Turkey is one of the few powers in the region that is stable outside of Russia which is currently locked out of the international financial market.  They will be flooded with safe harbor investments that will depreciate their currency; only way out will be to impose some sort of controls.  This is a real possibility for their government.
This is a hard question. For me it is easier to split it in two questions:
The government will run out of the cash
Unlikely as a weaker currency helps its exporters ..and it has low commitment to low inflation
Investors will be spooked by civil unrest.

1. Check "current account balance" ongoing.
2. Check leading indicators - determine where separate macroeconomics are moving.
3. There have been 37 capital control events in the last 25 years. Do research on each one.

Turkey Economic Growth:  November’s conclusive vote has helped to dissipate political uncertainty. That said, ongoing geopolitical risks and the possibility that the Central Bank will have to tighten its monetary policy further in order to protect the lira represent the main downside risks to Turkey’s outlook. On the other hand, a new government committed to implementing structural reforms could boost potential growth. FocusEconomics Consensus Forecast panelists GDP forecast for 2016 unchanged at 3.0%. For this year, the panel also expects the economy to expand 3.0%.

Imposing capital controls are a significant sign that the country is in severe stress and that the options available are few.  No question their address is in a turbulent part of the world and the mass refugee crisis is a significant strain.  On the positive side, they are seeing positive credit growth to private companies and households.  In addition, they are a benefactor of low oil prices, current negotiations with the EU on the refugee crisis, they don't really have an exposure to Chinese growth, and they are an important location for military presence for the ISIS fight.
Nobody much likes capital controls, but in the coming months Turkey has more reasons to resort to them than just about anybody else.
Ongoing strife in region. Syrian refugee crisis draining resources. Econ gloom becomes downward spiral. Capital controls imposed in attempt to strengthen.

Capital controls are a drastic step and not taken lightly. In recent years, Iceland, Cyprus, Greece have taken this step in response to very acute situations. Otherwise, ther are not that many examples aside from significantly less developed economies in Africa etc.  Capital controls do not happen often in relatively sophistical economies and when they do it is usually in response to an acute situation that has developed over a significant amount of time rather than as a shock response.

Given the Fed just raised rates, one must adjust the odds of this higher. Without parsing Yellen's statement here, assuming the Fed gets to their target of 3.5% for the Federal-funds rate; there's a reasonable chance this change in interest rate differential could ignite a wider emerging market selloff. This is a contingent probability outcome, one which comes down to interpreting or empathising with Erdogan's reaction function. To have greater clarity, one would need to get an idea of his economic beliefs to inform this position.

Doing some searching, I find it notable how few news stories there are about the possibility of Turkish capital controls (I can't find any recent ones apart from the FT story).  This doesn't seem to be a live issue.
Their economy is doing better than expected.
Very very unlikely especially under this administration. Because most of the money comes from abroad are from their supporters, relations etc. They can not kill that relations.
I can't see the parallels between Turkey and Greece / Cyprus etc.

Capital controls are more harmful to economies than the opposite, although this is an oportunity for corruption. But as the economies are more and more intertwined this kind of practices tend to have more opposition from foreign investors.
Turkey will be reluctant to impose capital controls.
They will be pressured to do so by EU. There is a small chance Erdogan might fight the EU on this.
They cannot afford to do it.
A definite trick up this country's sleeve, to hold onto its chips, unless something great happens economically to ease its hand off the control freak lever.
Its tensions with Russia will actually smooth economic relations with the EU and the U.S.

Turkey seems to be at the front line on starting WWIII and risks being abandoned by EU, NATO and Russia which means no more foreign investment inflows.  Turkey will follow (lead?) other EM's in trying to trap capital as its internal and external security situation worsens.  Upping forecast further post leaked memo relating to Thailand.

Turkey went through major debt fueled expansion under Erdogan, something which has probably run its course and then some. This in turn is connected to broader EM  slowdown.  Turkey with significant dollar denominated debt is at risk if the dollar substantially strengthens (likely other side of the coin to EM slowdown).  Imposing capital controls would also fit with Erdogan's "blame the foreigners " default mode.  And he now has the political authority to do as he wishes, if he wants to impose capital controls. That said, timing is everything when making bets on bond spreads,  just ask John Corzine.
The Lira continues to sink, short term loans coming due, Erdogan pressure on the Central Bank causing it to paint rozy pictures.  Not now for controls, but the pressure builds.

Current Account Balance to GDP is high (CAB/GDP), which means internal savings is too low. Economies which cannot provide enough money to finance their investments, have to attract foreign capital. 
The strength of the Turkish Lira has strengthened since 2003. http://article.sapub.org/image/10.5923.j.economics.20140406.02_008.gif.  Overvaluation of domestic currency increases consumption and importation, and reduces export values.
Short term debt percentage since 1994 has drastically declined (98% vs.5%). This improves the capability of a country to create a smoother international borrowing structure.

This is tough, especially since we're focused on ISIS oil fields at the moment. Turkey has been working with ISIS for oil and providing them with weapons. If you don't know this, you will soon enough.

Strong incentive for Turkey to impose controls given (1) risk of Syria issue expanding into Turkey (2) continuing currency weakness (3) continuing domestic economy issues (4) general economic weakness in EU (5) unlikely that EU will admit Turkey into EU (6) continuing issues within EU between member states, political and economic and (7) attempts by Turkey to get NATO assistance.  ie Turkey's attempts at getting shelter from other countries (EU / NATO) is not working and so Turkey will either (1) turn to Russia for assistance; may seem unlikely given the recent shooting but since NATO is not playing ball, it may be akin to Cuba during the Cold War or (2) impose currency controls.  Standing alone is not likely since it will have escalating civil unrest or be brought into / enter directly the Syrian war.  Currency controls are important before all capital leaves the country.  If Russia assists then capital controls may not be put in place so that Russians can use Turkey's openness for their own purposes
They are trying to enter the eu and with tensions with Russia and restrictions from Russia they need more trade. That move hamper growth.

Turkey's spat with Russia is going to exacerbate their growing economic woes. The underlying problem there, and in many other EM countries is the combination of a strong US dollar and weak commodity prices; this is hurting many of their traditional trading partners. In addition, all of the major economies are doing their darnedest to export deflation (i.e. prop up their own economies by printing money), and this is hurting smaller countries. If the governor of India's central bank isn't sleeping well at night, then smaller economies are going to be in even tougher shape.
No, capital controls often make economic crises worse.
Turkey's problem is too much property debt and too many imports.  Capital flight is not likely to become a crisis in 2016

There's going to be considerable turmoil between Turkey and Russia in the next year.  I'm not convinced Russia will remain in the driver's seat.  Additionally an economic downturn doesn't have to lead to capital controls.

It will be a litmus test of the stability of Turkey as the gateway to the West.  They have not resolved their religious issues and this puts them at greater risk then the stability required to keep capital flight at bay.  The shooting down of the Russian aircraft is only the beginning.  Refugee issues abound and will get worse.  Kurdish situation still an open sore.  Lots of flash points but little in the way of resolutions.

Capital controls are not uncommon for developing economies, Turkey is vulnerable to economic weakness from their current account deficit and geopolitical pressures. Still early days, start moderately negative
Capital controls are not as popular in certain circles as they once were.  However, Turkey's situation is such that as a stopgap this looks awfully appealing.
Turkey is definitely in a bad position, but imposing capital controls would be quite a drastic step, so would require significant continued deterioration.
Intuitively I find austerity measures to be negatively correlated with shooting down Russian warplanes.  I know it's probably the opposite but this is my gut.

http://news.markets/bonds/emerging-market-investors-should-keep-a-close-eye-on-turkey-3335/
"Turkey’s weak fundamentals, high debt levels, and sensitivity to capital flow volatility mean an increased risk of capital controls being introduced there, according to Fay Ren, investment analyst at fund manager Cerno Capital.
. . .
“Nonetheless, the end of quantitative easing and the expectation of rate rises in the US may see a reversal of the trend of flows that have been fundamental to Turkey’s economy; signs of this are just beginning to emerge. This will make funding more expensive and debt more difficult to repay, thus making Turkey more vulnerable to capital flight, taking into consideration that almost 25% of their bonds are held by foreigners. These eventualities are often precursors to the introduction of the foreign investor’s nemesis – capital controls,” Ren adds."
